comment._content: What a photo! I particulary love the smart expression in the player's eyes...This picture really tells a story.

comment.author: 79843095@N00
comment._content: Possibly a story about cheating. What's with the four of clubs tucked under the player's leg on the right?

comment.author: 34314291@N04
comment._content:
Yes, you're right Mark! I hadn't seen it!

In addition, the fact that the three players belong to different generations makes me think that they are having a lesson on how to cheat by the eldest one of them!

How many stories can be read in such great photos!

comment._content: Buenísima!

comment.author: 23091738@N00
comment._content: The boy at the centre of this carefully posed photograph has been situated so as to obscure the photographer's reflection in the mirror behind him.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
You are right Canterbury Heritage about the reflection, but it is not a mirror - it is a window with lace curtains inside (see persistent URL view).   These people are 'arranged' on an enclosed verandah with French doors.  None of the reflecting surfaces including the beer bottles, show the photographer, who would have had a black cloth over his head, I suppose.  The camera is also set very low, about the table top height.

The composition, hats (they are indoors), and bentwood chairs remind me of French Impressionist paintings, but I am not sure which one.  Anyone know?

Would imported bottled beer from England and Belgium have been a rare luxury item in 1890s Australia?  
Is that "Bulldog Brand" Tom Roberts' signature?

comment.author: 23091738@N00
comment._content: You're certainly right about a window rather than a mirror. Re-interpreting a 17th century Dutch theme, in the early 1890s Paul Cézanne produced five versions of The Card Players at Aix in his native Provence. This one is from 1892.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Thank you Canterbury Heritage, that is way too spooky!  I have chills up my spine!  Even the pipe on the table . . .  I see some of the other Cézannes also have bottles on the table.

I would bet that the photographer (Tom Roberts?) had seen the Cézannes in the early 1890s, and was recreating his mental picture.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I've been returning to this pic on and off for months...and I'm still none the wiser...one possibility is that they might be playing out a scene in a novel, or even a play...or maybe this is a still taken on the set of an early motion picture... Of course, among the superstitious, in cards (and probably life as well), the four of clubs is deemed to be unlucky...here the player on the right appears to be holding only four cards...suggesting that they have either dropped or discarded the four of clubs which we see face up on the seat beside their leg...though they appear to have covered the 4th club on the card, as if to counter the bad luck...the player on the left has what looks like a patch of dense hair growing on their arm...is this a blemish in the photo, or is it the mark of the Devil? Maybe they're about to turn into a warewolf? Here's a somewhat less sophisticated sub-tropical version www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryqueensland/8383038402/
